Situation1: Communicate openly to resolve conflicts or misunderstandings.
Expectation2: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation2: The mentor fit the session into the last hour before boarding a long flight.
Story: I stared at my phone, my sister’s name flashing on the screen. We’d argued earlier, and she wanted to talk things through, to clear the air before the tension grew. I knew how important it was to communicate openly, to show her I respected her feelings and valued our relationship. But at the same time, my mentor had just messaged, confirming she could squeeze in a session with me before her flight. She’d made time for me in her packed schedule, and I didn’t want to waste her effort or seem ungrateful. My heart pounded as I weighed the phone in my hand, torn between answering my sister’s call and logging into the video session. Both expected my full attention, both deserved my respect. I felt the pressure mounting, guilt and anxiety twisting together as I tried to figure out how to be a good sister and a good mentee at the same time.
